reviewText:
Although not as strong with it's gameplay as Gundeadligne, Gundemonium has superior visuals and a fantastic soundtrack.
This game is better for a single player experience!

Gundeadligne:
-Multiplayer but sadly rare that anyone plays so get a friend, in-game it suddenly gets insane at difficulty 21 (Demonic).
-Visuals less detailed and has outline better for seperating the background from the foreground.

Gundemonium:
-Single player but is strong with it's levels and has a better climb in difficulty compared with Gundeadligne.
-Visuals sharper and more detailed but can be difficult to look at over the background at times (especially later level 3).

Both equally good games but for different reasons.

Purchase Verdict:  Yes

Points of Interest-Undoubtedly some of the best musical compositions of any bullet hell game. The files are also readily avaliable in a convienent folder for importing into your Music Player.

reviewText:
So, you want to play a Shoot Em Up, do you? Well this game is definitely a good one to start with.

The game has four controls, plus 8-way movement. It's a side scroller, like the Gradius games, but it has no powerups. You use what the character you select has, as well as one of four alternate costumes which change their way of playing.

Music in this game is what you'd expect from a game from overseas; really good. It's not overbearing, and you can hear everything in the game without the music blocking anything. Plenty of different songs in each level, too.

Level design goes from Easy to moderate to a bit tough to really tough to If you are not godlike
date: quit now" tough. Difficulty ramps up REALLY fast towards the third level
recommended: which is only 10~ minutes in. The fifth level is just incredibly brutal
hoursPlayed: and this isn't even a hard game. Consider it an entry to Bullet Hells
voteText: because this is only the tip.\n\nA great game for beginners to learn the fear of Bullet Hell games. I'd like to think of myself as a fan of shooters
helpfulPercent: and I own a few on consoles
votesHelpful: but Bullet Hells continue to make me realize that I haven't even begun playing hard games. Get this if you want an introductory to a challenging genre of games that actually takes some skill."

reviewText: It would be against my standards not to reccomend a game made by Aeju Murasame. This and the other games in the Gundemonium bundle are the first of his games to be officially released overseas, but he is well-known in Japan, and it shows. The graphics are sublime, the game runs super-smoothly in most recent PCs, and the game system assures you think your tactics carefully if you wanna score high and unlock stuff. Plus, the remixed music is awesome, and unlike in the PS3 release, censorship is optional (There are a few lightly-dressed anime chicks in this game. <.<). Do you like Bullet Hell games? Have you played Touhou, but are FED UP of it (Like me) and want to try something different? Then buy the full bundle. You will not regret it at all.

reviewText:
Gundemonium Recollection is a side-scrolling shooter, and is the first in the Gundemonium trilogy. I have really tried to understand this game, but the game refuses to let me know what's going on. No tutorial, no explanation of what's going on, no explanation of the buttons, moves or attacks. Obviously, the basic shooting action is easy enough to grasp, but without understanding how the bombs and special attacks work, you can't really succeed at the game.

Shooter fans that are looking for a challenge and are willing to research this game to figure it out may enjoy it. Also, if you don't mind just blindly shooting at things and dying a bunch, you may be able to forgive this game's flaws. For most people, however, I'd recommend passing this one up, unless you can find it for under a dollar.

UPDATE: I've had a few complaints come in, so I'm going to address a few of the points I missed the first time around.

First, the manual. Yes, there's a manual, and yes, it teaches you basically everything you need to know about playing the game. No, it's not good enough, and no, it doesn't replace the missing tutorial. Here's the first problem: I didn't have access to the manual when I played the game initially. I was traveling and had no Internet connection, which is a huge problem when the online manual is required reading to enjoy the game. Also, game manuals haven't been required reading for basically any game made since 1990. Most manuals made today only contain basic troubleshooting information for the game, so the manual is not where I would have thought to look for basic gameplay instructions. I mean, seriously, it doesn't take that much effort to put in a basic, working tutorial. Why didn't the developers care enough to include one?

Also, this game is fairly complex, which is unfortunate because the game is so inelegant. There are lots of little meters and little rules quirks you're just expected to know about. There are plenty of bullet hell shooters that have rich gameplay with a relatively simple set of rules. This is not one of them.

Second, the controls. If you're playing on a keyboard, the control menu is simply baffling. Not only do you not have the option to freely bind the keys, but the game also doesn't adequately tell you what the current bindings are. Fire is 01"? Which key is that? If you think it's the 1 key
date: you're wrong. It's the space bar.\n\nThird
hoursPlayed: I read the blurb at the start. It makes little sense. It's a giant wave of jargon with almost no meaning
voteText: and the inter-level blurbs are similarly void of semantics. It doesn't adequately explain what's going on.\n\nAs for the gameplay
helpfulPercent: I'm willing to take back a little of what I initially said
votesHelpful: since the manual addresses a few of my concerns. That said
votesTotal: as far as bullet hell shooters go
votesFunny: this is still on the lower end of quality.\n\nI still don't recommend this game. This game is very lazily made
commentsCount: and fans of bullet hell shooters deserve better. Thankfully
column16: there are better ones out there
column17: though I'm not aware of any that are currently on Steam (Ikaruga's not on Steam yet)."

reviewText: The most polished shooter in the Gundemonium series. This horizontal shmup plays like a vertical shmup, complete with two movement speeds, subweapons, and a complicated ranking system that dynamically adjusts the difficulty based on how you play.Waves of enemies are passed by killing a certain number of enemies in that wave, and picking up extends and bombs on later waves incentivizes strong offensive play. Difficulty levels start off trivial but end in the realm of impossible, with normal only really becoming uncomfortable near the end. The game is loaded with extra missions and features, and you can even customize the Earl Type ships, but Eryth is still the main character and therefore the best.

reviewText: The most polished shooter in the Gundemonium series. This horizontal shmup plays like a vertical shmup, complete with two movement speeds, subweapons, and a complicated ranking system that dynamically adjusts the difficulty based on how you play.Waves of enemies are passed by killing a certain number of enemies in that wave, and picking up extends and bombs on later waves incentivizes strong offensive play. Difficulty levels start off trivial but end in the realm of impossible, with normal only really becoming uncomfortable near the end. The game is loaded with extra missions and features, and you can even customize the Earl Type ships, but Eryth is still the main character and therefore the best.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Gundemonium is a normal shmup in a lot of ways, but with a couple of unique twists. You've got your normal shmup fare, attack, special attack, bomb... there's also a neat rapid fire attack that will overheat a certain character's guns if you use and on another it's worthless. The most unique thing in this game is the phase level mechanic. Depending on what difficulty you start on, your phase level will change, with demonic locked in at 11. The higher your phase level, the harder the game is. You can lower your phase level by getting hit or using a bomb, or raise it by beating a boss or using a bomb just as you get hit, also known as counter bombing.\n\nYour hitbox is very small in comparison to your large sprite, which allows bullets to cover most of your body without you getting hit. Personally, I would prefer a larger hitbox or a smaller sprite, but it isn't a big deal. Espcially considering this game's difficulty. It's a pretty difficult game. Do not buy this if you are not prepared to die often. That's really the only reason to stay away, or if you just don't like bullet hell games. I love this game, and I highly reccomend it.
